citation.article-title: Capnocytophaga haemolytica sp. nov. and Capnocytophaga granulosa sp. nov., from human dental plaque.

p.s: Description of Capnocytophaga granulosa sp. nov.
Capnocytophaga granulosa (gra.nu.lo'sa. L. adj. granulosa, granular)
Cells are thin, gram-negative rods (5 to 8 by 0.3 to 0.4 μm).
Granular inclusions that are stained by basic fuchsin are observed at the ends and in the middle of Gram-stained cells.
These inclusions are clearly observed when the strains are grown anaerobically at 37°C in GAM broth for 5 to 7 days.
Flat, thin colonies with uneven edges are 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 5 to 7 days on TBBP agar.
No hemolysis occurs on TBBP agar or blood agar.
The colonial colors are gray to purple on TBBP and blood agar plates but yellow or orange on Trypticase soy agar.
Pellets of cells obtained by centrifugation after washing with distilled water are yellow or orange.
Cultures grow under microaerophilic conditions and can grow well on blood agar incubated at 37°C in the presence of 5% CO2.
Susceptible to actinomycin D.
Acid is produced from D-glucose, D-lactose, D-maltose, D-mannose, starch, and D-SUcrose.
Negative for oxidase activity, catalase activity, nitrate reduction, H2S production, and indole production.
No acid is produced from cellulose, D-mannitol, D-ribose, D-sorbitol, D-xylose, dextran, glycogen, and inulin.
Aminopeptidase positive with some of the substrates listed in Table 4.
The major end products of glucose fermentation are acetate and succinate.
The major menaquinone is MK-6.
The dominant cellular fatty acids are i-15:O and 18:0 acids.
The G+C content of the DNA is 41 to 42 mol%.
Strain B0611 (= JCM 8566) is the type strain of C. granulosa.
The characteristics of this strain are the same as those given above for the species.
The G+C content of the DNA of this strain is 41.7 mol%.
